newsitem.title: SUDAN: Khartoum state tries to enforce sexual segregation.
newsitem.headline: Khartoum state tries to enforce sexual segregation.

text.p: Khartoum state has decreed strict sexual segregation in public, in line with the government's puritanical vision of an Islamic society.

Under a decree approved by the state parliament and published on Wednesday, men and women cannot sit together in public and men may not watch women playing sports. Sportsmen cannot wear tight or short clothes which expose the body.
It reiterates the ban on coeducation in schools. In higher education men and women students must sit apart.
At public gatherings, theatres, cinemas and so on, a curtain must divide the men from the women and on marches they will have to walk in separate groups, it says.
The rules, which apply only to Khartoum city and environs, do not differ greatly from ones issued in 1991 and largely ignored by the police and the general public.

Sudan's present rulers took power through a military coup in 1989. The dominant ideological group is the National Islamic Front of parliamentary speaker Hassan al-Turabi, who wants to turn Sudan into an exemplary Islamic society.
Other bans in the decree include:
-- Women may not sit next to drivers.
-- Women can go shopping at night only in the company of their husbands or other close male relatives.
-- Men must have good reason for walking along streets leading to schools for girls or places where women gather.
